text: Prions associated with human brain disease are thought to be aberrantly folded forms of a normal brain protein (PrPC).
The prion is now recognized as an infectious, misfolded protein that resists inactivation by procedures that destroy proteins.

The theory is that when a prion, designated PrPSc, is introduced into the body and manages to enter the brain, it will cause normally folded forms of the damaging aggregated structures within brain cells.
The discovery that proteins alone can transmit an infectious disease came as a surprise to the scientific community.
Diseases caused by prions are especially worrying, since prions resist destruction by many chemical agents and remain active after heating at extremely high temperatures.

There have even been documented cases in which sterilized neurosurgical instruments, originally used on a prion-infected person, still held infectious agent and transmitted the disease to a subsequent surgery patient.
An unusual infectious agent called the prion has been implicated as the cause of a series of relatively rare but invariably fatal brain diseases (Table 26.7).
PrPSc aggregates called amyloid form and damage the brain.
ingestion or other means and causes the slow refolding of normal PrPC proteins to PrPSc.
Extremely rigorous decontamination procedures, such as autoclaving surgical instruments How can a nonliving entity without nucleic acid be an infectious agent?
The protein alone can mediate an infection.
Prions are infectious agents that do not have a nucleic acid genome.
Imagine slowly losing your mind and knowing there is nothing you can do about it.
